titleStmt.title: Letter from Millicent Fawcett to Thomas Hardy — 15 April 1892

physDesc.p: Single letter on cream paper with printed address “2, Gower Street.” Written in dark ink, with portions overwritten or corrected in a lighter hand.

profileDesc.abstract: Millicent Fawcett writes to Thomas Hardy praising *Tess*, discussing the moral meaning she believes fiction should convey to young readers, and her work assisting vulnerable girls.

handDesc.handNote: Dark ink, cursive hand; occasional overwriting in lighter ink.

profileDesc.note: Millicent Garrett Fawcett (1847–1929) was a leading English suffragist, feminist, and writer, connected with social purity and education causes.

projectDesc.p:
Diplomatic TEI P5 transcription with for uncertain readings and
for line breaks.

body.p: I do not expect you will remember me but I will try to recall myself to you by mentioning that I had the pleasure of meeting you & Mrs Hardy at Lady Portsmouth’s London house two or three years ago.
I have been very full of admiration for your *Tess* and of real gratitude to you for writing it, but I should

not have intended so far to tell you this which must be an old story to you.
My object in writing is to ask if you
—no one could do it half as well—
would write a short story within the limits of thought and language that could be readily comprehended by working boys & girls on the shipwrecks of what ought to be the most beautiful thing in their lives—what comes of treating love between man & woman with lightness and irreverence.

What I want to see made plain in a story is that the very holiness & beauty of the thing, at its best, makes any trifling with only the physical part of it result in corruption— “Lilies that fester smell far worse than weeds.”

I work with some friends to help girls who have gone wrong to get on their feet again and we see so much of the utter want of apprehension that there is any high and noble side to this thing that they have gone shipwreck upon; it is difficult to get even a glimmer of it through to them, and I imagine it would be even more difficult in the case of men of the corresponding type.
Could a small prose help to make it obvious that men may read?
body.closer:
Believe me yours very faithfully,
Millicent Fawcett
